NOTES: 



A correction was noted on May 27, 2010 in the Executive Summary. The correction was a typo regarding the total quantity of sulfur dioxide on site. The previous submittal was completed using the 2004 RMP*Submit and a diskette, which allowed the submitter to document one "Program" under section 7 for similar processes. For that submittal, one "Program" was completed for the Chiller Group A, B, anc C ammonia processes. For the 2010 correction, the software does not appear to allow for one "Program" when there are multiple processes; therefore, the answers provided for process #78244 were repeated for processes 78242 and 78243. There is no new equipment or processes associated with this submittal.



A correction was made to the RMP in December 2011 to address the sulfur dioxide incident that occurred on February 2011 and to reflect the change in the emergency contact.



The RMP was updated in September 2012 to address the installation of a fourth ammonia refrigeration system (Chiller Group D), which has a maximum intended inventory in excess of 10,000 pounds.



A correction was made to the RMP in February 2013 to reflect the change in the RMP Responsible Person and to correct the ammonia inventory for Chiller Group A.  This revision also addresses minor changes to this document based on The Wine Group's review.



The RMP was updated in November 2013 to meet the five year revalidation requirement.



The RMP was updated in July 2015 to address the changes to Chiller Group A.



The RMP was updated in February 2016 to address the changes to the sulfur dioxide process.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Senior management at the facility is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safe environment for all employees and the surrounding communities. Senior management administers the safety and environmental policies and programs at the faclity. These programs include but are not limited to forkl

ift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturers' documentation, Emergency Action Plan, as well as the Risk Management Plan. 



The Wine Group, Inc. facility has independently coordinated emergency response efforts with the local Fire Department. In the case of an ammonia related or sulfur dioxide-related emergency, it is the policy of The Wine Group, Inc. to evacuate the employees and to allow the fire department/HazMat team to respond to the emergency. If an ammonia or sulfur dioxide release could potentially impact the local community, a Community Notification Plan would be activated. If an ammonia or sulfur dioxide release were to extend into the neighboring community, a Shelter-In-Place plan would go into effect.



The Wine Group, Inc. personnel circulate throughout the plant, taking note of unusual conditions in any portion of the system. In the event that an ammonia or sulfur dioxide leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger, and The Wine Group, Inc. Maintenance Manager and Safety Representative (Supervisor). The Supervisor will determine what procedures and personnel are necessary to remedy the problem. Emergency agencies will also be notified as necessary as outlined in the Emergency Action Plan.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The Wine Group, Inc. facility is located at 17000 E. Highway 120 in Ripon, California, which is on the 120 Highway and approximately 5 miles east of Highway 99. The area immediately surrounding the facility is rural with farmland and residential areas.



Ammonia Systems:

The primary business of The Wine Group, Inc. is the production and processing of grape juice, wine, and distilled spirits.  In order to conduct operations, the facility currently uses a maximum of 140,356 pounds of ammonia in its four independent ammonia refrigeration systems.

The four systems (A, B, C, and D) each contain the following charge of ammonia: 38,000 pounds, 35,628 pounds, 35,628 pounds, and 31,100 pounds, respectively.  The refrigeration systems, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment (compressors, evaporative condensers, pressure receiver, chillers, and suction accumulator, and Glycol Circulation System and Tank Jacket Heat Exchangers/Coolers), cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration to wine product and/or glycol.  Typical operating conditions range from approximately 10 psig on the low pressure side of the system to 180 psig on the high side.



Sulfur Dioxide Systems:

Sulfur dioxide (SO2) is used to preserve wine and is injected directly into the wine and into the wine storage tank headspace. The sulfur dioxide is located at a single filling station with a maximum of one (1) active one-ton cylinder at the filling station and five (5) one-ton cylinders in storage adjacent to the filling station. The one-ton sulfur dioxide cylinder at the filling station is connected to a fixed-piping system by flexible hoses. The piping system provides a way to transfer the sulfur dioxide to smaller dispensing cylinders (6 pound, 25 pound, and 100 pound capacities). Operators fill the dispensing cylinders at the filling station and then inject SO2 from these smaller cylinders into the wine or into the tank headspace as needed. The facility uses a 100 pound cylinder fixed to a portable dispensing cart to add SO2 to the headspace of wine tanks.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (CalOSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Section 5189 of Title 8, CCR) and th

e EPA Risk Management Program (RMP).  This prevention program covers those processes that handle sulfur dioxide and ammonia above the threshold quantity of either PSM or RMP rules.



The prevention program provides a structured approach to preventing accidents.  Some of the specific activities in the prevention program include:



- Process safety information is provided to all applicable employees upon hire and is accessible at all times.

- In depth process hazard analyses are completed every five years by qualified personnel using techniques approved under the PSM standard.

- Written operating procedures (kept up to date) are used for training and guiding the work of operators.

- Training is provided to all employees upon hire, and refresher training is given at least every three years or upon request.

- Operators, mechanics, and contractor personnel are qualified, trained in the general hazards in the facility, and informed of any temporary situations affecting safety.

- Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted to insure that conditions for safe operation have been satisfied prior to starting new or modified equipment.

- A program is in place to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process, which includes written procedures, training requirements, equipment deficiency requests for employees, work orders, scheduled maintenance, and documentation.

- A hot work permit system assures that work is done safely and properly.

- A management of change system is in place to ensure that changes are managed safely.

- Incidents are investigated and actions are taken as part of a continuous improvement effort.

- Routine audits are conducted to assure that safe practices are being followed.



This systematic approach to process safety involves employees and strives for continuing improvements in overall safety.  The training, qualifications, and safety awareness of our operations, maintenance, and management personnel are a key element in reducing and mitigating

accidents.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Between February 2011 to February 2016, there has only been one release of a regulated substance from covered processes that meet specific EPA criteria for the Five-Year Accident History (see Section 6 of the EPA RMP Registration and the incident summary below regarding the sulfur dioxide release that occurred on February 23, 2011).  Such "RMP accidents" would involve serious accidents with either onsite deaths, injuries, or significant damage; or known, off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, or environmental damage. The Wine Group, Inc. (Franzia Ripon) realizes that the community may also be interested in smaller releases of regulated chemicals that do not meet such criteria. We have been diligent in reporting releases of hazardous materials and internally investigate and correct the causes of such releases.



Ammonia Systems:

An investigation into the facility's accident history showed that there have been no RMP reportable releases of anhydrous ammonia that over the past five years (February 2011 - February 2016) that meet specific EPA criteria for the Five-Year Accident History (see above definition).



Sulfur Dioxide Systems:

Between February 2011 and February 2016, the facility had one RMP reportable incident that meets the above definition. On February 23, 2011, approximately 5 pounds of gaseous sulfur dioxide was released through a transfer hose failure, resulting in the injury of one employee. No other onsite impacts occurred, no off site impacts and no environmental or property damage occurred. Off-site responders were notified but did not respond. The results of the internal incident investigation showed that improved/upgraded equipment and revisions to maintenance, training and operating procedures were needed.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (plan) in effect. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



?    save lives;

?    minimize and avoid inju

ries;

?    protect the environment; and

?    minimize property damage.



The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia and sulfur dioxide health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the CalARP regulations.



In case of an ammonia or sulfur dioxide emergency, the facility plans to evacuate all employees and alert the local emergency responders (fire department). The facility plans to coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Chemical safety is an important part of The Wine Group, Inc. facility located in Ripon, California.  The Health and Safety committee as well as regulatory requirements have minimized chemical exposure risks to employees and the public through ongoing internal risk reduction efforts.  For example, as a result of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), vehicle barriers were recommended to be installed around the ammonia processes and detailed procedures were documented.  



Other improvements will be made when identified and approved by Management.
